newsitem.title: THAILAND: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - Dec 2.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Thai newspapers - Dec 2.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Thai press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- His Majesty the King has warned members of the new Cabinet to honour their pledges to work in the best interests of the country and for the benefit of the people. Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh will hold his first Cabinet meeting today, to kick-start his election pledge to heal the ailing economy and push for political reform, among other issues. (THE NATION) (BANGKOK POST)

- Representatives of more than 150 non-governmental organisations have urged the new government to take serious action to tackle AIDS problem. The Thai NGO Coalition on AIDS has issued a statement urging the government to consider three main points in drafting its policy, expected to be announced to Parliament on December 11. (BANGKOK POST)

- Deputy police chief Salang Bunnag has told military officers that he ordered the extra-judicial killing of the six drug suspects in Suphan Buri province last Wednesday. General Salang said earlier that the six handcuffed suspects were killed after they tried to grab the policemen's guns. He denied they were executed by his men after they had given themselves up and released three hostages unharmed at a house where they were arested. (BANGKOK POST)

- Thai and Malaysian officials have agreed to simplify customs procedures to support intra-regional trade in the Indonesia-Malaysia-Thailand growth triangle. Under the agreement, one standardised bill of lading will be required, replacing the current documents that differ in detail and need checking by customs officers before imports are released. (BANGKOK POST)

- Wirat Wattanasiritham, newly appointed chief of the National Economic and Social Development Board (NESDB), has announced a major effort to block a critical exodus of key economic planners. He says a restructuring aimed at increasing staff roles could help resolve the situation. (THE NATION)

- A consortium of MDX Power Plc, Italian-Thai Development Plc and Japanese conglomerate Marubeni, is contemplating building a hydro-power dam and electricity plant in Burmese territory with a capacity of 100-200 megawatts. The project will supply electricity to the state-run Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand. (BUSINESS DAY) (THE NATION)
